1 AUGUST.part4: And the king said unto Zadok, carry back the ark of God into the city: if I shall favour in the eyes of the LORD, He will bring me again, and shew me both it, and His habitation.
1 AUGUST.part5:
After the people had left Jerusalem, King David instructed Zadok and Abiathar to go back with the ark. He was not superstitiously thinking that the ark gave blessing and deliverance as was the mistake of others in the past [1 Samuel 4:3- 11]. At that battle, the Philistines had captured the ark, and Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of high priest Eli were killed. While David knew its construction was ordered by God, he would not make an idol of it.

The ark contained manna, Aaron's rod that budded and the tablets of the Law. These reminded the Israelites of God's providence, God's ordained priest's authority and God's holiness and revealed way to live. However, David sought God Himself and would not commit the sin of idolatry by elevating these objects to the level of God. These items were not to be looked to for deliverance.

David acknowledges that God is sovereign and were he to re-enter Jerusalem, it would be because of God's favour and grace. He is submitting to God as the sovereign, gracious and personal God that He has revealed Himself to be. David is totally surrendered to God's will and His sustaining grace. He is not merely voicing his desire to return. His trust and reliance run so deep he is prepared, that should God not be pleased with him [v. 26], he will submit to God's ordained outcome. David hopes to see the ark and the temple again for they represented His presence and His habitation, but above all he desired God Himself, not the physical trappings.
1 AUGUST.part7: The objects in the ark pointed to the Lord Jesus Christ, in whose completed work of salvation on the Cross, we are able to come boldly into God's presence with praise and thanksgiving.

2 AUGUST.part3: VERSE 29 for the people in Jerusalem to worship God. He
2 AUGUST.part4: Zadok therefore and Abiathar carried the ark of God again to Jerusalem: and they tarried there.
2 AUGUST.part5:
David's son Absalom had usurped the father's throne. David had to flee after Absalom had commandeered the palace. High priest Zadok brought the Ark of the Covenant along with them when David fled Jerusalem, but he instructed both Zadok and Abiathar (another high priest) to return with the Ark to Jerusalem. The purpose for them to return was twofold: Firstly, to attend to their priestly functions and secondly, to spy on Absalom.

Though he was on the run, David's heart was for the people in Jerusalem to worship God. He was concerned for their spiritual well-being lest they fall away. He wanted Zadok and Abiathar to be guiding, teaching and leading in the worship of God there. David knew how the Jews turned to idols in the past when they lost the guidance of godly priests. This was Zadok and Abiathar's primary responsibility.

David was also thinking how he might eventually return. He needed to know what Absalom was planning so he could make his own strategic moves. Both Zadok and Abiathar were to act as David's eyes and ears in Jerusalem. This was the second reason for sending them back.

We draw near to God through prayer and reading His Word. When we walk with Him, we will be obedient to His teaching. One of His commandments is to love our brothers. David so loved his subjects that he sent Zadok and Abiathar back to Jerusalem with the Ark. We may be pious in church on Sunday but how are we on the other six days? How does our walk with God look like when we are away from the company of God's people?
2 AUGUST.part7: Lest there should be among you man, or woman, or family, or tribe, whose heart turneth away this day from the LORD our God, to go and serve the gods of these nations; lest there should be among you a root that beareth gall and wormwood. - Deuteronomy 29:18

3 AUGUST.part4: And David went up by the ascent of mount Olivet, and wept as he went up, and had his head covered, and he went barefoot: and all the people that was with him covered every man his head, and they went up, weeping as they went up.
3 AUGUST.part5: King David's prowess was renowned. He had won many wars. He slew the giant. He was battle-seasoned and a valiant soldier. Now he was reduced to a refugee, a fugitive running from a son whom he loved very much. He trudged barefooted up mount Olivet. There he could see Jerusalem. Surely, he reflected on his own sins; how he plotted a loyal servant's death so he could take his wife. David had many other wives and could have many more, but he coveted the only one who belonged to Uriah! What regret must have flooded the heart and mind of David when he saw the royal city lost to a turncoat. There he wept with a heavy heart, remorseful for his sins and sorrowful that a son of his own blood had done this to him. But David prayed. The erstwhile lord and king of Israel was praying to the King of kings, Lord of lords. Our Lord Jesus was also on mount Olivet (Mount of Olives) looking at Jerusalem. And He wept. David wept for himself, but the Lord Jesus was weeping for the people in their sins and a city soon to be destroyed. God loves each one of us, but we were lost in sin and turned against Him. The Lord Jesus wept for the depravity of man. He loved us and was sorrowful for us. He would die to redeem us from our helpless state. Hallelujah, He rose from death and lives again. And if we accept Him as our Saviour, we will also rise and live with Him again.
3 AUGUST.part7: And when He (our Lord Jesus Christ) was come near, He beheld the city (Jerusalem), and wept over it. - Luke 19:41

4 AUGUST.part3: VERSE 32a God instructs us to worship Him in His sanctuary
4 AUGUST.part4: And it came to pass, that when David was come to the top of the mount, where he worshipped God.
4 AUGUST.part5:
He was in desperate straits, hopeless by human standards, but Scripture recorded that David worshipped. He was in an uncomfortable position and place in life, but David did not blame God. Instead, he worshipped Him. His faith did not falter with his circumstances. David wrote Psalm 3 on this occasion. God is never far away but with us at all times. We may have forgotten Him, but He does not forget us.

God instructs us to worship Him in His sanctuary and to assemble with the brethren. However, when this is not possible, as in this pandemic, we thank Him that we are still able to worship Him at home. Wherever we are, we worship with reverence for the Lord is holy. The place of true worship is in the heart. Therefore, we are to watch our hearts and mind how we worship.

This is a great mystery. God is already glorious, and our worship contributes not one bit to make Him more glorious. But still, He desires it and thus we worship Him. We need Him in our lives. He created us, loves us, deals with us according to His mercy through grace. Our Lord Jesus gives us eternal life by forgiving our sins. He bestows countless blessings upon us. We are thankful and grateful, so we worship God. It is our expression of love and reverence for Him alone. And it is an honour that He gives us the opportunity to do this.
4 AUGUST.part7: Give unto the LORD the glory due unto His name; worship the LORD in the beauty of holiness. - Psalm 29:2

5 AUGUST.part2: David's worship of God (II)  PSALM 3:8 Salvation belongeth unto the LORD: Thy blessing as upon Thy people.  To CompLtete THE BiBLeE
5 AUGUST.part4: Salvation belongeth unto the LORD: Thy blessing is upon Thy people.
5 AUGUST.part5:
This Psalm gives us insight into the mind of David as he fled from his own son.

In verse 1, we see David feeling very discouraged. He perceived that many foes had risen against him. This led to his reflection in verse 2, where he shared what other Israelites might have thought of his plight - that even God had forsaken him.

However, we see that while David might have been feeling this way, in verse 3 he picked himself up by looking to God. He testified in the subsequent verses that as he cried out to God for deliverance, God answered his prayer. David testified to the inner peace that he experienced so that he was able to sleep each night knowing God would be gracious to him. The psalm ended on a triumphant note as David testified how God had helped him defeat his enemies, and he gave all glory to God. It is not David's strength that is emphasised here. Rather, the king's weaknesses are in full view, but we see God's strength being sufficient for him. And this leads him to engage in sincere and joyful praise.

In our times of distress, we can look to this Psalm and draw encouragement from it. When we are able to testify of God's goodness in our lives no matter what, then we worship Him in spirit and in truth. Such is sincere experiential worship.
5 AUGUST.part7: Do I meditate on what God has done for me so that I am able to thank and praise Him in spite of my circumstances?

6 AUGUST.part4: And it came to pass, that when David was come to the top of the mount, where he worshipped God, behold, Hushai the Archite came to meet him with his coat rent, and earth upon his head:
6 AUGUST.part5:
This is the first time that Hushai is mentioned in the Bible. We know little of who he is save that he later became King David's companion [1 Chronicles 27:33]. Here, however, Hushai appeared as God's answer to David's prayer. When David heard that wise Ahithophel had defected and joined Absalom, he had prayed [2 Samuel 15:31] for God to intervene and make Ahithophel's counsel come to naught.

In the next verse, we see God beginning to answer this prayer through the appearance of Hushai. The first things that Hushai provided to David was comfort and sympathy. He came with rent coat and earth upon his head as a sign of shared grief. Hushai expressed visibly sympathy and empathy for the king's plight. We do not know what was going through Hushai's mind at that time, but he came and was available to the king in his time of need. Little did he himself know he would be of help to David.

When we encounter others in trouble or sorrow, do we have enough love to feel their grief with them? Are we willing to offer support by our actions? We may not know exactly how we can be of help; nevertheless, let us just be there and available as vessels and channels for our Master's use.
6 AUGUST.part7: Channels only, blessed Master, But with all Thy wondrous pow'r Flowing through us, Thou canst use us, Every day and every hour. - Mary E Maxwell

7 AUGUST.part4: Behold, they have there with them their two sons, Ahimaaz Zadok's son, and Jonathan Abiathar's son; and by them ye shall send unto me every thing that ye can hear.
7 AUGUST.part5:
Here we see Hushai's loyalty in supporting David in his moment of need. God's answer to David's prayer for help was timely indeed and came almost instantly in response. We may be impatient when God does not seem to answer us straight away. Just remember God's answers are never late.

"Here we have met Yahweh's delightful providence again. How it must have heartened David. No sooner does he pray than Yahweh begins to answer his prayer - and that in a way no scriptwriter could have guessed. Our prayers deal with the what: God's answer deals with the what, the how and the when. And how the how can surprise us!" (Dale Ralph Davis, 2 Samuel). God always gives more than we deserve. And His answers can be surprising indeed.

At this point in time, Hushai's presence by Absalom's side was more helpful to David than his companionship. David ordered him back to serve Absalom with the motive to thwart Ahithophel's counsel.

Is it right for David to send Hushai on an errand that is morally dubious? Some would argue that war and diplomacy, subterfuge, deception and camouflage should be part of one's stratagem. We have to admit that in this case, Hushai's loyalty to David is commendable, but it is not Christian morality. And even in ordinary life, there are times when expediency overrides ethics. However, we have to bear in mind that this is a historical narrative, meaning to say that we must not assume that God approves everything that is recorded in Holy Scripture. If anything, David's scheme and Hushai's unquestioned loyalty show us that our morality falls far short of God's teaching.
7 AUGUST.part7: Good ends do not justify bad means.

8 AUGUST.part4: And when David was a little past the top of the hill, behold, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth met him, with a couple of asses saddled, and upon them two hundred loaves of bread, and an hundred bunches of raisins, and an hundred of summer fruits, and a bottle of wine.
8 AUGUST.part5:
We first met Ziba in 2 Samuel 9. He was a servant of Saul. When David became king after Saul, he had asked whether anyone remained from Saul's house that he could show his kindness to him [2 Samuel 9:1]. Ziba was the man who led David to Mephibosheth, Jonathan's lame son. David took Mephibosheth in, caring for him as he had promised Jonathan [1 Samuel 20:14-15]. Because of this hesed covenant, this son of Jonathan would eat continually at the king's table [2 Samuel 9:13].

David had also left instructions for Ziba, "Thou therefore, and thy sons, and thy servants, shall till the land for him, and thou shalt bring in the fruits, that thy master's son may have food to eat ..." [2 Samuel 9:10]. It should be a relief for this servant of the previous king, that the new king not only spared his life, but also retained him to continue what he had been doing before, thus allowing Ziba to maintain his successful and comfortable status quo. And Ziba was not a poor servant, for we are told he had fifteen sons and twenty servants then.

But Ziba was not a contented man, and he would prove himself an unworthy steward. Seven chapters later, avarice had totally consumed him. He had much, yet wanted more. As David departed in haste from Jerusalem, Ziba devised a wicked plot. Coming before the king with his gifts, Ziba schemed to accuse Mephibosheth and secure David's favour at the expense of his master.
8 AUGUST.part7: And He said unto them, Take heed, and beware of covetousness: for a man's life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth. - Luke 12:15

9 AUGUST.part4: Then said the king to Ziba, Behold, thine are all that pertained unto Mephibosheth. And Ziba said, I humbly beseech thee that I may find grace in thy sight, my lord,
9 AUGUST.part5:
Ziba met David with generous and helpful gifts. He prepared saddled donkeys, food and wine to help relieve and refresh David and his men. When David asked about Mephibosheth, Ziba informed that his master was in Jerusalem. Ziba was manipulative. He lied to David insinuating that Mephibosheth was there awaiting the power of Saul's house over Israel to be restored to him. This was pure slander.

This implied that Mephibosheth had betrayed the king's kindness and was disloyal. It also made Mephibosheth appear to wish for David's destruction. 2 Samuel 19:24-30 tells us Ziba betrayed his master and slandered him. It was a shameless and despicable act since it was untrue and especially when he knew David would be disheartened that the son of his loyal best friend Jonathan had turned against him during his crisis.

Ziba had cunningly schemed to gain David's favour. Without verifying Ziba's information or pondering it over, David hastily rewarded Ziba with all the possessions that pertained to Mephibosheth. David should at least have been a little sceptical about Ziba's words and sought counsel from God. The Bible tells us that "he that answereth a matter before he heareth it, it is folly and shame unto him" [Proverbs 18:13].

Seek wisdom and discernment from the Lord. Be still in the Lord and set aside time to pray and receive His counsel. Do not be troubled by afflictions. Pray for God's help to be wise and discerning, patiently waiting for His answer. As stated in Proverbs 8:14, "Counsel is Mine, and sound wisdom: I am understanding; I have strength."
9 AUGUST.part7: O God, I pray that You protect us from all evil and give us wisdom to discern good and bad. Guide us to make wise choices in accordance to Your will. May I seek You more and more. Amen.

10 AUGUST.part3: VERSE 6 and his servants. Depressing as it already was for
10 AUGUST.part4: And he cast stones at David, and at all the servants of king David: and all the people and all the mighty men were on his right hand and on his left.
10 AUGUST.part5:
David's next encounter was with a man called Shimei as they approached Bahurim, a city northeast of Jerusalem, belonging to the tribe of Benjamin. Shimei was a Benjamite and a distant relative of the former king. Shimei harboured personal hatred and enmity against David. He resented David and attributed the fall of Saul to him.

Shimei was enraged and threw stones at David and his servants. Depressing as it already was for David to be betrayed and overthrown by his own son, it must have been even worse for him to bear now these unwarranted curses from Shimei. Shimei's offensive words were unjustified because David did not cause the fall of Saul's kingdom or his death.

David wrote Psalm 7 in response to the slanderous accusations of those who claimed he was responsible for Saul's death. Instead of taking revenge himself, David cried out to God for justice against those who persecuted the innocent. He took refuge in the Lord and asked God to deliver him from his pursuers.

Oftentimes, we too are hurt by people's unfounded slanders and accusations. Do not rush to take revenge but pray and seek the Lord for comfort and vindication. We can trust that He will help us through our darkest moments and restore us. He is the God of justice, strength and victory.

11 AUGUST.part4: The Lord hath returned upon thee all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose stead thou hast reigned; and the Lord hath delivered the kingdom into the hand of Absalom thy son: and, behold, thou art taken in thy mischief, because thou art a bloody man.
11 AUGUST.part5:
Shimei hurled abusive words at David. He cursed "come out, come out ... " which literally is "go out, be gone out of thy kingdom, as thou deserve", accusing David to be a man of blood and exulting that God was repaying him for all his deeds. Perhaps he was thinking of Uriah's murder. But certainly, he accused David of being responsible for "the blood of the house of Saul" including Abner [2 Samuel 3:27] and Ishbosheth [2 Samuel 4:8], Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua [1 Samuel 31:2-3].

David took Shimei's curses with humility. He was unprovoked by Shimei's false accusations, but he must have been grieved by those malicious words. David was scoffed at, mocked, humiliated, unfairly treated and falsely accused. But he turned to the Lord for hope, encouragement and strength. He wrote Psalm 69, where he cried out to God in his distress. He was physically exhausted and mentally devastated. Yet David trusted in the Lord and sought refuge in Him.

When we are down and disappointed, rejected and hopeless, do not give up. Seek the Lord's help to overcome in His strength, joy, grace and glory. Then, remember to thank God for what He has done for us. Worship and praise God for His marvellous love and divine power. God our heavenly Father is always in control.
11 AUGUST.part7: Be submissive, be faithful and be righteous. Always remember God's goodness and mercy. Be thankful and know that God will execute justice in His time.

12 AUGUST.part4: And the king said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah? so let him curse, because the LORD hath said unto him, Curse David. Who shall then say, Wherefore hast thou done so?
12 AUGUST.part5:
David did not try to shut up Shimei. He did not close his ears to unpleasant and critical words. David let Shimei speak because he saw the hand of God in every circumstance. David was willing to hear what God might say to him through a cursing critic. Instead of retaliating as his friends wanted to do, David resigned himself to God's providence.

Though God does not cause evil to happen to us, He sovereignly allows it because the testing of our faith strengthens it over time. Dealing with verbal abuse and hurtful comments is exhausting but lashing out in response is never helpful. When David refused to retaliate, he was able to be refreshed. David's reaction models a healthy response to unjust ridicule.

What would you have said? Think about a person who is a thorn in your flesh. How relieved you would be if that person was no longer in your life! How tempting it must have been for David to say, "Deal with him." Just a word and all would have been over for Shimei. If you are the subject of hateful remarks, first consider if there is reason for them? If you have caused offence, can you ask for forgiveness and restore the relationship? If the hurtful words were said simply out of spite, what can you take from David's example to follow? How can you handle the situation in a way that will show God's presence in your life?
12 AUGUST.part7: A soft answer turneth away wrath: but grievous words stir up anger. - Proverbs 15:1

13 AUGUST.part3: VERSE 11 David's life thereafter was just the reaping of what
13 AUGUST.part4: And David said to Abishai, and to all his servants, Behold, my son, which came forth of my bowels, seeketh my life: how much more now may this Benjamite do it? let him alone, and let him curse; for the LORD hath bidden him.
13 AUGUST.part5:
David saw the hand of God even in being maligned and cursed by Shimei. He knew that God had called him to walk through this valley of humiliation. Shimei added insult to David's injury. But there was some truth to his chastisement of the king. David was hardly innocent. He had taken the life of innocent Uriah and would be called to account by the righteous Judge. He was forgiven but would have to bear the consequences of his actions. The chain of sorrowful events that dogged David's life thereafter was just the reaping of what he had sown in those few unguarded moments when he saw, lusted and took. So, David accepted that the Lord had sent this man to curse him. If the Sovereign God had willed and directed this, then no one could question it, least of all David.

It is always easy to see the hand of God, when good things are happening to us. But, when bad things happen, we quickly forget God is also in the picture. The bad experience, painful trial or unkind person is all we see. But David did not lose sight of God in the dark moments of his life. He knew the Lord was there and in control.

Are we constantly mindful that God is working in every moment of our life? Whether circumstances are good or bad, God is always working it for good to those who love Him. If we submit to Him, He will ultimately turn the cursing into a blessing and our mourning into rejoicing.
13 AUGUST.part7: God is always present where you are, and He is always at work.

14 AUGUST.part4: It may be that the LORD will look on mine affliction, and that the LORD will requite me good for his cursing this day.
14 AUGUST.part5:
Although David had committed no murder on the house of Saul, and Shimei's cursing was nothing but malicious accusations, David felt it was deserved because of his sins, though not for the sin he was being accused of. The venom of Shimei's words was nothing compared to the guilt in David's heart and the pain of Absalom's rebellion. And he sought comfort in the possibility that God might yet overrule this trouble for his own ultimate blessing.

David submitted to the Lord's chastening. It was better to be at God's mercy than to take matters into his own hands. He could accept God's judgement because God's grace was greater than David's sin. He spoke not so much with assurance, but only with hope. He knew what his sins deserved but he had hope God would deal mercifully with him.

David reminds us that we can turn to the God of grace who will yet bless. At this point in David's life, he was not sure what God was doing to him. But he had hope that God could turn those curses into blessings. If you are struggling with the consequences of your sin, let David's words encourage you. Even as you face the reality of sin in your life, turn to God and seek His forgiveness. The God of grace delights to forgive and restore.
14 AUGUST.part7: Biblical hope is not wishful thinking, but a confident expectation. "Blessed is the man that trusteth in the LORD, and whose hope the LORD is." - Jeremiah 17:7

15 AUGUST.part4: And the king, and all the people that were with him, came weary, and refreshed themselves there.
15 AUGUST.part5:
Shimei would not go away. As David made his way to Bahurim [v. 5], this nasty man followed, cursing and casting stones and dust at them. This was a way of saying, "I wish you were dead."

At times in life, we may seem to be plagued with a problem that will not go away despite our earnest prayers. The apostle Paul spoke of the thorn in his flesh he had entreated the Lord thrice to remove but it was not to be. Instead, Paul learnt the sufficiency of God's grace and strength through that perpetual painful problem [2 Corinthians 12:7-9].

Then we see here an interesting thing that happened. We are told that David's band came weary to Bahurim, encountered surliness and inhospitality, but found refreshment there, in the unlikeliest of places. It was as though a little candle had been lit and its light was cutting through the fog of gloom.

This is the secret of God's presence with every child of His. It is not dependant on circumstances, it does not look to people and it can be in any place. Even in the most trying of times in our lives, when everything seems to be going wrong, all hope lost, closest of friends desert us, and enemies curse and throw stones at us, we can find refreshment at our Bahurim because the Lord will meet us there.

Well might David have reflected on this occasion when he penned the 31st Psalm: "Thou shalt hide them in the secret of Thy presence from the pride of man: Thou shalt keep them secretly in a pavilion from the strife of tongues. Blessed be the LORD: for He hath shewed me His marvellous kindness in a strong city" [v. 20-21].
15 AUGUST.part7: And He said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for My strength is made perfect in weakness. - 2 Corinthians 12:9a

16 AUGUST.part4: And Hushai said unto Absalom, Nay; but whom the LORD, and this people, and all the men of Israel, choose, his will I be, and with him will I abide.
16 AUGUST.part5:
Hushai, a loyal friend of David was sent back to defeat the counsel of Ahithophel, who had joined Absalom in his coup. But returning now to Jerusalem was risky, for his friendship with David was no secret. Such a hazardous undertaking surely had little chance of success especially with Ahithophel there providing counsel to Absalom.

Appearing before Absalom, Hushai greeted the king royally. Absalom naturally was suspicious and questioned Hushai's defection from his friend. Instead, Hushai pledged allegiance to the divine appointment and popular choice of the people. But note that Hushai did not name the king to whom he would give allegiance and serve [v. 18- 19]. His answer was astute. These were the right words in a tricky situation. It would allay Absalom's suspicion and doubt. Absalom would feel Hushai was indeed a welcome asset to his cause. Absalom may even have thought this was a confirmation from the Lord that the kingdom was now his, with both Ahithophel and Hushai joining him.

This account speaks just as much of Absalom's self-delusion as of Hushai's astuteness. Absalom's conceit blinds him to the improbability of Hushai's supposed desertion of David. If he were wise, Absalom would have asked Hushai, "Is this how you treat your king and friend?"

The same question may be asked of Demas who forsook Paul because he loved this present world [2 Timothy 4:10]. Our Lord Jesus directed a similar question to the twelve, "Will ye also go away?" [John 6:67], after the multitude returned "and walked no more with Him". It may well be asked of backsliders who walk no more with our Saviour.
16 AUGUST.part7: What a Friend we have in Jesus! Remember therefore your vows of love, loyalty, and service to our Lord Jesus Christ, our royal Friend.

17 AUGUST.part4: And again, whom should I serve? should I not serve in the presence of his son? as I have served in thy father's presence, so will I be in thy presence.
17 AUGUST.part5:
Hushai's testimony of loyal service and being a trusted friend to the king was well-known and recognised. Such are rare virtues and useful in the royal court. He served not only the appointed king but also the LORD God Himself. Before Absalom, he asserted his disregard for political rivalries but pledged allegiance to whomsoever God, in His providence, had appointed king. All he wished was to be useful to the king and contribute to the growth and prosperity of the kingdom.

In word and deed, he showed honesty and unflinching loyalty. Such qualities in a man would be the king's delight to have beside him and in his service. "He that loveth pureness of heart, for the grace of his lips the king shall be his friend." [Proverbs 22:11]

What a joy and honour to be a personal friend of the highest in the country, to have his trust and be of use to him. Is the Lord Jesus, who is higher than the highest on earth, your King? Hear what He said, "Henceforth I call you not servants; for the servant knoweth not what his lord doeth: but I have called you friends; for all things that I have heard of my Father I have made known unto you" [John 15:15]. God called Abraham His friend [Isaiah 41:8]. Christians, what a Friend we have in our Lord Jesus! He is the Word that reveals to us the heart of God, His thoughts, His mind and His will. In Him we can confide our innermost thoughts and secrets. Let us show our frevent love to our King and Friend by our faithful service.
17 AUGUST.part7: Ye are My friends, if ye do whatsoever I command you. - John 15:14

18 AUGUST.part4: And Ahithophel said unto Absalom, Go in unto thy father's concubines, which he hath left to keep the house; and all Israel shall hear that thou art abhorred of thy father: then shall the hands of all that are with thee be strong.
18 AUGUST.part5:
To establish Absalom as the new king and for his own self-preservation, Ahithophel sought to cause an irreconcilable divide between son and father, and strengthen the hands of those who supported him in the coup. He advised Absalom to publicly commit abominable fornication with his father's concubines [Deuteronomy 27:20].

In ancient times among the pagan nations, appropriation of the royal harem was an act demonstrating subjugation and domination of the throne. Ahithophel under the cover of this sought revenge, for he was grandfather of Bathsheba, daughter of Eliam his son [2 Samuel 11:3; 2 Samuel 23:34]. When David ordered the death of Uriah to conceal his adulterous sin and take Bathsheba to be his wife, the seed of hatred and revenge was planted in her grandfather's heart. What David shamefully did with Bathsheba, Ahithophel now counselled Absalom to do the same with David's concubines. What David did to Bathsheba's husband, he plotted to repay in kind to David himself. Absalom willingly submitted to Ahithophel's counsel for he was eyeing the throne. Ahithophel by his counsel was eyeing vengeance.

Fallen men with unregenerate hearts are able to conceive and commit the most deplorable acts. Their depraved minds have neither regard for God's holy law nor their own reputation. "The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked: who can know it?" [Jeremiah 17:9]. Ahithophel, the adviser, and Absalom, the actor, were both culpable for this heinous sin in God's eyes. Let us be careful when we give counsel to others that we do it for their good and not for our gain. And let us when seeking man's counsel to always measure it against the perfect standard of God's revealed Counsel.
18 AUGUST.part7: Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned. - 1 Timothy 1:5.

19 AUGUST.part4: And the counsel of Ahithophel, which he counselled in those days, was as if a man had enquired at the oracle of God: so was all the counsel of Ahithophel both with David and with Absalom.
19 AUGUST.part5:
Ahithophel was widely known as the king's counsellor [1 Chronicles 27:33]. He occupied the honoured position at the king's right hand. The counsel he gave was regarded as coming from a "seer", one who could see visions from God and even the future. He and the former king made an excellent pair. David could have been writing about their partnership in his psalm, "We took sweet counsel together, and walked unto the house of God in company" [Psalm 55:14].

Absalom also sought Ahithophel's counsel and conspired with him to overthrow David. It is likely he knew the relationship of Ahithophel with Bathsheba and Uriah, and the injustice Ahithophel's family suffered. He could certainly relate to this because his half-brother Amnon had raped his sister Tamar and David did nothing. Sharing the same grievance, they now shared the same goal. In this successful plot, Ahithophel would play a vital role.

To whom do we go for advice in times of crisis or major decisions? We do well to first seek Him whose name is called Wonderful, Counsellor [Isaiah 9:6] and seek His Word. Joshua and the princes "asked not counsel at the mouth of the LORD" when dealing with the Gibeonites and were deceived [Joshua 9:14b]. Then let the Lord lead us if need be, to godly brethren and spiritual leaders. Beware counsel whose end does not glorify God and whose means violate God's Word. "Do not open your heart to every man but discuss your affairs with one who is wise and who fears God" (Thomas a Kempis).
19 AUGUST.part7: Most counselling problems reflect a distorted view of God and a deficient relationship with Christ. - Robert Jones on Counseling the Hard Cases

20 AUGUST.part4: And I will come upon him while he is weary and weak handed, and will make him afraid: and all the people that are with him shall flee; and I will smite the king only.
20 AUGUST.part5:
Chapter 17 begins with Ahithophel giving another piece of advice to Absalom. His advice should be read in light of the preceding verse - that Ahithophel's counsel was regarded as almost divine. Clearly, Ahithophel possessed great wisdom and his advice would be critical to Absalom's success.

Ahithophel knew Absalom was not safe as long as David lived. He proposed launching a surprise attack on David with an elite force. They would strike while David was tired and discouraged and before he could rally his troops. Once smitten, David's supporters would flee in fear while the rest would reunite under the new king.

Absalom and the elders of Israel were pleased with Ahithophel's advice. We can see that Ahithophel indeed had a good grasp of the situation. David and his men were weary and disorganised at that point. Had Ahithophel gone for the kill that night, he likely would have succeeded.

Ahithophel had no qualms about killing the king, even offering to lead this "murderous" mission personally. This is in stark contrast to David who before had steadfastly refused to harm Saul despite having the opportunities, means, and good "excuse" to do so. Whereas David esteemed king Saul as the Lord's anointed, Ahithophel had neither fear nor regard for God's anointed or for God Himself.

As brilliant as Ahithophel's plan was, the outcome is in the hands of the Lord. We may not know the unrevealed will of our Sovereign God, but we may rest assured that those who despise Him will be lightly esteemed by Him.
20 AUGUST.part7: ... for them that honour Me I will honour, and they that despise Me shall be lightly esteemed. - 1 Samuel 2:30

21 AUGUST.part4: And I will bring back all the people unto thee: the man whom thou seekest is as if all returned: so all the people shall be in peace.
21 AUGUST.part5:
It is interesting to note Ahithophel's argument in verse 3. He reasoned that killing David would unify the nation under Absalom. Lives lost are deemed necessary for unity.

In the wisdom of the world, it makes eminent sense to get rid of anything that stands in the way of achieving one's goals. Political rivals must be removed before the people can unite under one leader. Even the murder of one's own father may be justified in the name of bringing unity and peace under one kingship.

But Israel is a nation unlike any other for it is a nation established by God. Ultimately, God is her king; the human king is but a man appointed by God to govern and rule on His behalf. There is no unity except under the kingship of God, administered by His anointed. To Ahithophel, however, power and throne, peace and unity, can be obtained through political manipulation and the use of force.

Our Lord showed us that God's kingdom is not one of violence but of peace. Instead of getting rid of us sinners, He rids us of sin and the wrath we deserve by bearing them Himself on the cross for all who put their trust in Him. It is His atoning sacrifice that brings all believers together as one in the body of our Lord Jesus Christ. So for Christians, unity is not obtained by getting rid of opponents. True unity can only be found at the foot of the cross when we submit to His lordship over our lives.
21 AUGUST.part7: With all lowliness and meekness, with longsuffering, forbearing one another in love; Endeavouring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace. - Ephesians 4:2-3

22 AUGUST.part3: VERSE 5 Absalom. Why would Absalom want a second
22 AUGUST.part4: Then said Absalom, Call now Hushai the Archite also, and let us hear likewise what he saith.
22 AUGUST.part5:
After Ahithophel had given his counsel to Absalom, the usurper sought Hushai's view on Ahithophel's proposal, thus giving him the opportunity to influence Absalom's decision.

It is inexplicable that Absalom should consult Hushai. Earlier, he had questioned Hushai's loyalty for not having gone with David [2 Samuel 16:17]. Although Hushai proffered some verbal assurance, he had done nothing to prove his allegiance to Absalom. Why would Absalom want a second opinion from him now? Absalom and the elders favoured Ahithophel's plan, and Ahithophel had a stellar reputation as a king's counsellor. One would reasonably expect Absalom to have more confidence in Ahithophel's advice than to consult another whose loyalty was in question.

But providence would have it that Absalom desired a second opinion. Perhaps he wanted the plan to be as failsafe as possible. This would mark the beginning of his downfall. Absalom did not merely seek Hushai's advice on what he thought best to do, he also divulged Ahithophel's entire plan and invited Hushai to critique it. Once Hushai knew what he was up against, he was able to devise a way to thwart Ahithophel's plan and buy time for David to regroup his forces. He began by boldly asserting to Absalom that his trusted counsellor's advice was "not good at this time", and followed that by using cunning rhetoric to undermine Absalom's confidence in Ahithophel's advice. Even as the two influential counsellors vied for the king's heart, we know that it is God's counsel that will ultimately stand.
22 AUGUST.part7: Remember the former things of old: for I am God, and there is none else; I am God, and there is none like me, declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times the things that are not yet done, saying, My counsel shall stand, and I will do all My pleasure. - Isaiah 46:9-10

23 AUGUST.part4: And he also that is valiant, whose heart is as the heart of a lion, shall utterly melt: for all Israel knoweth that thy father is a mighty man, and they which be with him are valiant men.
23 AUGUST.part5:
Hushai used clever words to convince Absalom that Ahithophel's advice was worthless. In effect, Hushai was telling Absalom: "Do you really think Ahithophel can kill the king so easily? You know that your father and his men are a mighty force. Furthermore, they are enraged right now. Like bears robbed of their cubs, they will put up a fierce fight and your father is an expert in warfare. He will not camp with his troops but will hide in a place impossible for you to find. It is your men who will be killed. Once rumours of defeat spread, even your bravest soldier will panic. After all, everyone in Israel knows what mighty warriors your father and his men are."

Absalom bought the argument. We know the reality was closer to Ahithophel's assessment - David was exhausted rather than enraged; he was not hiding in any pit; he had not regrouped his forces; and at times he had even become too complacent to lead his army into battle. Nevertheless, David's fame as a mighty warrior preceded him. His reputation, built up over the years, enabled him to command fear and respect for his military prowess even among his enemies.

What does your reputation say about you? Does it reflect a transformed life in Christ? Does it enhance your Christian testimony, or does it cause others to doubt the authenticity of your faith? Does it glorify God, or does it give people a reason to slander?
23 AUGUST.part7: A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, and loving favour rather than silver and gold. - Proverbs 22:1

24 AUGUST.part4: Therefore I counsel that all Israel be generally gathered unto thee, from Dan even to Beersheba, as the sand that is by the sea for multitude; and that thou go to battle in thine own person.
24 AUGUST.part5:
Ahithophel called for a swift attack targeted at David himself. Hushai, however, advised Absalom to move cautiously and mobilise a massive force to wipe out David and all his supporters. The army would be gathered from across the land and led by Absalom. They would seek and destroy David and his men. Even if David were to hide in a city, they would tear it down to hunt him out.

Much as Ahithophel excelled in military strategy, Hushai surpassed him in craftiness. Hushai knew how to appeal to Absalom's vanity for this was Absalom who had surrounded himself with a retinue of chariots, horses and men to impress the citizens [2 Samuel 15:1]. Hushai's plan would allow Absalom a full display of pomp and pageantry at the head of a huge army. And rather than Ahithophel getting the credit for killing David, Absalom would receive the "honour" as their commander. Furthermore, this plan would also display his military prowess by eradicating all those alongside David.

In reality, Absalom's chance of success was grossly exaggerated. Hushai's plan served David's interest, not Absalom's. The time it would take to amass such an army would give David time to recover and regroup. Putting Absalom at the forefront of battle would ensure his ruin. Nevertheless, Absalom fell for Hushai's subterfuge. He who has a deceitful heart is now blinded by his own vanity and becomes the deceived.
24 AUGUST.part7: The human heart has so many crannies where vanity hides, so many holes where falsehood lurks, is so decked out with deceiving hypocrisy, that it often dupes itself. - John Calvin

25 AUGUST.part4: And Absalom and all the men of Israel said, The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Ahithophel. For the LORD had appointed to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, to the intent that the LORD might bring evil upon Absalom.
25 AUGUST.part5:
Why did Absalom choose the proposal of Hushai over that of Ahithophel even though the latter's plan was tactically superior? Some commentators believe it was partly due to Hushai's cunning in appealing to Absalom's ego throughout his lengthy presentation. Maybe, but that does not explain why even Absalom's generals changed their minds after they had earlier expressed satisfaction with Ahithophel's plan. The real reason is found in the second part of verse 14; it was the intent of the Lord to bring evil upon Absalom. It was God's unseen hand "worketh all things after the counsel of His own will" [Ephesians 1:11].

It is the privilege of Bible-believing Christians to be able to see God's unseen hand in the glove of history. Here we see it in the case of Absalom; first in his decision to seek a 'second opinion' from Hushai [v. 5], and then favouring his proposal. We see this also in numerous events recorded in the Bible, such as Daniel being brought "into favour and tender love with the prince of the eunuchs" [Daniel 1:9], and Esther obtaining "grace and favour in (the sight of King Ahasuerus) more than all the virgins" [Esther 2:17].

As Christians, we are to trust the Lord with all our heart and lean not unto our own understanding [Proverbs 3:5]. Let us stay confident and comforted that, regardless of the circumstances in our lives, our God will cause all things to "work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to His purpose" [Romans 8:28].
25 AUGUST.part7: The king's heart is in the hand of the LORD, as the rivers of water: He turneth it whithersoever He will. - Proverbs 21:1

26 AUGUST.part4: Now therefore send quickly, and tell David, saying, Lodge not this night in the plains of the wilderness, but speedily pass over; lest the king be swallowed up, and all the people that are with him.
26 AUGUST.part5:
In David's psalms, he often thanked God for delivering him from his enemies. For example, in Psalm 18, he used the word "deliver" seven times to acknowledge God's deliverance. Today's passage is another such occasion where David managed to escape from Absalom's army. As in an earlier incident when David escaped Saul's assassins through the help of his wife Michal [1 Samuel 19], here he receives help from those God sent.

As soon as Hushai left the meeting with Absalom and his generals, he hastened to report to David via the priests Zadok and Abiathar as instructed by David earlier [2 Samuel 15:35]. The two priests then sent a maidservant to relay this information to their sons Jonathan and Ahimaaz who were waiting by the spring at Enrogel outside Jerusalem. There was no time to waste as it was likely Hushai did not know which proposal Absalom had adopted, his or Ahithophel's. Even if Absalom had accepted his, there was still the danger he could change his mind. David must immediately cross the Jordan before he and his troops are "swallowed up" by Absalom's army.

As followers of our Lord Jesus Christ, we too can call upon the Lord in our hour of distress and know that our cry will come before Him, even into His ears [Psalm 18:6]. Rest assured that the King of glory and Lord of hosts [Psalm 24:10] is able to deliver in the manner that is best for us and for the glory of His own name.
26 AUGUST.part7: Some trust in chariots, and some in horses: but we will remember the name of the LORD our God. - Psalm 20:7

27 AUGUST.part4: And when Absalom's servants came to the woman to the house, they said, Where is Ahimaaz and Jonathan? And the woman said unto them, They be gone over the brook of water. And when they had sought and could not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.
27 AUGUST.part5:
Ayoung man, possibly one of Absalom's spies, saw Jonathan and Ahimaaz talking to the maidservant and hurried back to report to Absalom. Realising they had been spotted, the two messengers fled and coming to a certain house in Bahurim, hid in the well in the courtyard. The brave woman of this house covered the well with a cloth, pretending to be drying the corn laid out on top of it. Her bravery and presence of mind saved their lives because Absalom would surely have killed them all if he found out the truth.

This nail-biting episode is yet another example of how the Lord used an ordinary woman to fulfil His plan for the redemption of mankind. We are reminded how Rahab saved the two spies in Jericho [Joshua 2] and ultimately became grafted into the line of David's ancestors. We also think of Esther, who apart from her physical beauty, was just an ordinary Jewish girl. But God used her to rescue the Jews from annihilation by Satan during the time of the Medo-Persian Empire. Thus preserved the children of Israel to welcome their Messiah, who would be born to the family of Joseph some four and a half centuries later.

The lesson of these stories for ordinary people like us is that we must be ready to serve the Lord when the opportunity arises; "and who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this?" [Esther 4:14].
27 AUGUST.part7: When God calls you, He enables you and He sees you through. - Warren W. Wiersbe in On Being a Servant of God

28 AUGUST.part4: Then David arose, and all the people that were with him, and they passed over Jordan: by the morning light there lacked not one of them that was not gone over Jordan.
28 AUGUST.part5:
The reader may heave a sigh of relief when he reads in verse 22 the happy ending in yet another dramatic episode in the life of David. The villain's plan is thwarted, and our hero escapes. Exciting though the narrative has been, still we all know there will be a happy ending because of the spoiler in verse 14, "that the LORD might bring evil upon Absalom".

This is the case throughout the Bible, whether it was the fate of Joseph in the Egyptian prison, Daniel in the lions' den or Mordecai in the Persian court. We know how the story will end because its Author says, "I am God, and there is none like Me, declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times the things that are not yet done, saying, My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure" [Isaiah 46:9b-10]. No wonder, Elwood McQuaid, author of the book It is No Dream, said that the history of Israel is pre-written history. God has already recorded it for us in Scripture.

This knowledge should give us the confidence to face the trials of life because we know who holds tomorrow. Warren Wiersbe said in his book, On Being a Servant of God, "If God has called you to minister, no matter what that ministry may be, He hasn't made a mistake. He knows what He's doing, and the best thing you can do is gratefully submit to His will and trust Him to work."
28 AUGUST.part7: Many things about tomorrow, I don't seem to understand. But I know who holds tomorrow, and I know who holds my hand. - Ira Stanphill

29 AUGUST.part4: And when Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his ass, and arose, and gat him home to his house, to his city, and put his household in order, and hanged himself, and died, and was buried in the sepulchre of his father.
29 AUGUST.part5:
Seeing that Absalom had rejected his counsel and chosen instead to listen to David's friend, Ahithophel decided to end his own life. His treacherous scheme to eliminate the former king had failed. His dreams had crumbled, and his carefully laid plans had come to nought. Hence, while David travelled to Mahanaim, Ahithophel returned to his home, set his affairs in order, and hanged himself. What caused him to do such a tragic thing?

Firstly, he could not bear the shame of being slighted. His ambition of being the power behind the new king appeared to be on the way to fulfilment until this unexpected turn of events. Secondly, his hope of leading the attack and basking in its victory had evaporated, leaving him without the power he sought. Thirdly, he assessed that inexperienced Absalom would be defeated. Given the needed time to recoup, David's battle-hardened and deeply loyal fighters would decimate Absalom's forces, after which he would be executed as a traitor. Basically, like Judas Iscariot, he must have sensed that he had been used by Satan and realised it was futile to "kick against the pricks" [Acts 9:5].

Ahithophel's fate teaches a precious lesson for all who live for the world, seeking wealth and success. Soon we will discover that all is vanity; and when things do not go our way, then there is nothing left worth living for. Let us seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness; let us wait on the Lord, and He will grant us the desires of our heart.
29 AUGUST.part7: For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? - Mark 8:36

30 AUGUST.part3: VERSE 24 Jacob declared upon seeing the host of God's
30 AUGUST.part4: Then David came to Mahanaim. And Absalom passed over Jordan, he and all the men of Israel with him.
30 AUGUST.part5:
David took the advice of Ahimaaz and Jonathan [v. 22], and fled to Mahanaim, a city on the other side of Jordan. Mahanaim was a fortified city with walls and gates, a suitable place to take refuge in [2 Samuel 18:24]. Importantly, Mahanaim was where David would be able to gather reinforcements. Mahanaim was also where the angels of God had met with Jacob, and where Jacob declared upon seeing the host of God's angels, that "this is God's host" [Genesis 32:1-2].

As David passed over to Mahanaim, Absalom too crossed the Jordan with his forces and pitched in the land of Gilead. Having accepted Hushai's advice, Absalom was now ready with all the men of Israel to engage David. Absalom replaced Joab with Amasa as the commander of Israel's army, appointing another of David's nephews to take charge of taking David's life.

Absalom's rebellion is staggering. He was not content with having ravaged his father's concubines openly [2 Samuel 16:22] and chasing his father out of Jerusalem to the other side of Jordan. At this point it was likely that Absalom had been already anointed as king [2 Samuel 19:10]. Yet Absalom's hunger to secure the crown and kingdom would not be satiated until he had utterly eliminated his father.

Absalom's open revolt turned a nation against itself, pitting family member against family. He forsook his namesake (Absalom means "father of peace") and pursued rebellion instead. Are we pursuers of God and peace, or do we find ourselves like Absalom, pursuing rebellion and our own desires?
30 AUGUST.part7: We need not fret ourselves because of evil men. Ultimately the evil will have no reward, and they will come to an end. Read Proverbs 24:19-20.

31 AUGUST.part2: Timely provision  VERSES 28-29 Brought beds, and basons, and earthen vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched corn, and beans, and lentiles, and parched pulse, and honey,  and butter, and sheep, and cheese of kine, for David, and for the people that were with him, to eat: for they said, The people is hungry, and weary, and thirsty, in the wilderness.  To CompLtete THE BiBLeE
31 AUGUST.part4: Brought beds, and basons, and earthen vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched corn, and beans, and lentiles, and parched pulse, and honey, and butter, and sheep, and cheese of kine, for David, and for the people that were with him, to eat: for they said, The people is hungry, and weary, and thirsty, in the wilderness.
31 AUGUST.part5:
At Mahanaim, David was received by distinguished hosts of great wealth and royalty: Shobi from Rabbah of the Ammonites was almost certainly from the royal family of Ammon, once an avowed enemy of Israel; Machir from Lo-debar, was a farmer who had taken care of Jonathan's son Mephibosheth and had been faithful to the house of Saul; and Barzillai the Gileadite was a wealthy man. These men met David in his need with great sympathy and substantial gifts.

So not only did David find refuge in Mahanaim, he also found hope in unlikely allies. This was the first sign that not everyone in Israel had fallen away from him. David and his men were comforted and relieved of hunger and weariness by these people's kindness. These men remain honoured today by their legacy of loving God and succouring God's people in their difficult times.

David was bereft of position, home, family and nation, but found comfort in the all-providing God. All manner of provision was made to David in a timely way. In the wilderness they had suffered want and scarcity. Here, they received plenty from their hosts and were strengthened for the battle ahead. Our God is a refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble. Even though everything around us may seem to be falling apart, we need not fear if God is with us, for He knows our every need.
31 AUGUST.part7: Day by day, and with each passing moment, Strength I find to meet my trials here; Trusting in my Father's wise bestowment, I've no cause for worry or for fear. - Carolina V. Sandell-Berg
